content.raw:
I've been playing with a slightly different approach [here](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branch/graph_generic_nate?dest=graph_generic#diff).

The main differences are:
1. No shared pointers.
2. Vertex and Edge data is stored consecutively in memory (*might* help with performance).
3. Changed "AddVertex" function parameter list to put name first, followed by data, then id. This feels a bit more natural to me.

I have left a bunch of parts commented out, and I ran out of time to implement directed vs undirected graphs. I think the difference can be handled in the `Edge` class without the need to subclass. It might even be possible to not required a Directed and Undirected graph subclass.

As usual, this is a suggestion that might be strewn with problems.
content.html:
I've been playing with a slightly different approach here.

The main differences are: 1. No shared pointers. 2. Vertex and Edge data is stored consecutively in memory (might help with performance). 3. Changed "AddVertex" function parameter list to put name first, followed by data, then id. This feels a bit more natural to me.

I have left a bunch of parts commented out, and I ran out of time to implement directed vs undirected graphs. I think the difference can be handled in the Edge class without the need to subclass. It might even be possible to not required a Directed and Undirected graph subclass.

As usual, this is a suggestion that might be strewn with problems.

content.raw: I wrote it as a set because I don't want to assume any order between the vertices. In a pair, there's a first and a second element.
content.html: I wrote it as a set because I don't want to assume any order between the vertices. In a pair, there's a first and a second element.

content.raw: There's a first and second element in a set too. Perhaps http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/unordered_set/unordered_set ?
content.html: There's a first and second element in a set too. Perhaps http://www.cplusplus.com/reference/unordered_set/unordered_set ?

content.raw: The elements are sorted in an `std::set` but that's an implementation detail. Specially, we're storing pointers to the elements, so when you insert your two vertices in the edge you're not specifying any order. An `unordered_set` is perfectly possible and will impact the performance of insertion vs search. I chose a regular `std::set` for speeding up the searches (which of course is arguable :)
content.html: The elements are sorted in an std::set but that's an implementation detail. Specially, we're storing pointers to the elements, so when you insert your two vertices in the edge you're not specifying any order. An unordered_set is perfectly possible and will impact the performance of insertion vs search. I chose a regular std::set for speeding up the searches (which of course is arguable :)

content.raw: Right, but I see this as an optional feature. That's why is not included in the generic `Edge` class but both `DirectedEdge` and `UndirectedEdge` contain the user data member.
content.html: Right, but I see this as an optional feature. That's why is not included in the generic Edge class but both DirectedEdge and UndirectedEdge contain the user data member.

content.raw: Looking at Nate's branch I'm guessing this has been discussed already, but I think users should not be given a shared_ptr to a vertex or an edge. Giving a user a shared_ptr tells them they can have ownership of the memory after the graph class is destructed. If the graph disappears the vertexes and edges have no meaning.
content.html: Looking at Nate's branch I'm guessing this has been discussed already, but I think users should not be given a shared_ptr to a vertex or an edge. Giving a user a shared_ptr tells them they can have ownership of the memory after the graph class is destructed. If the graph disappears the vertexes and edges have no meaning.

content.raw:
Similar points have been made on pull request #141. After reading some of the feedback on this pull request though, I'm now thinking there are two kinds of users of the Graph class:

1. Functions which will traverse the graph to do things like finding paths, cycles and searches (they would live in `GraphAlgorithm`)
1. Functions which will query the graph for data

For case 1, I think it should be fine to share ownership of some aspects of the graph. The scope of these functions should have a short life and during that life, we don't want the graph to be suddenly pulled away from them. If that's the case, we could make functions that return shared pointers be private members, and make `GraphAlgorithm` something like a `friend`. The downside I can see is that downstream users wouldn't be able to write their own functions to traverse a graph, unless the API provided by `GraphAlgorithms` is enough.

I think functions on case 2 could live longer. In this case, maybe they can keep an ID to the specific vertex or edge they're interested in, and use that ID to query the Graph later? And in case they want to traverse the graph, they can use that ID in conjunction with functions in `GraphAlgorithm`.
content.html:
Similar points have been made on pull request #141. After reading some of the feedback on this pull request though, I'm now thinking there are two kinds of users of the Graph class:

  1. Functions which will traverse the graph to do things like finding paths, cycles and searches (they would live in GraphAlgorithm)
  2. Functions which will query the graph for data

For case 1, I think it should be fine to share ownership of some aspects of the graph. The scope of these functions should have a short life and during that life, we don't want the graph to be suddenly pulled away from them. If that's the case, we could make functions that return shared pointers be private members, and make GraphAlgorithm something like a friend. The downside I can see is that downstream users wouldn't be able to write their own functions to traverse a graph, unless the API provided by GraphAlgorithms is enough.

I think functions on case 2 could live longer. In this case, maybe they can keep an ID to the specific vertex or edge they're interested in, and use that ID to query the Graph later? And in case they want to traverse the graph, they can use that ID in conjunction with functions in GraphAlgorithm.

content.raw:
It's an interesting suggestion. It should be possible. Are you suggesting:

 1. All functions should live in the new `GraphAlgorithms`  class except the data structures.
 1. Leave the `Graph` class as it is and create a new `GraphAlgorithms` class for high level functions, such as search algorithms?

Potentially, in the `GraphAlgorithms` class we lose the ability to access to the private members of the graph (unless we use friendship), but that's actually a good idea and a good use case for testing the iterators (work in progress), as they should hide the internal representation of the graph.
content.html:
It's an interesting suggestion. It should be possible. Are you suggesting:

  1. All functions should live in the new GraphAlgorithms class except the data structures.
  2. Leave the Graph class as it is and create a new GraphAlgorithms class for high level functions, such as search algorithms?

Potentially, in the GraphAlgorithms class we lose the ability to access to the private members of the graph (unless we use friendship), but that's actually a good idea and a good use case for testing the iterators (work in progress), as they should hide the internal representation of the graph.

content.raw:
This is the generic `Graph` class, which could be directed, undirected, etc. `Incidents(v1)` returns the set of edges  that allow going from any vertex `v` to `v1`. In the case of an undirected graph, this function should return all edges that contain `v1`. In the case of a directed graph, it should return all edges, where the head (the destination) of each edge points to `v1`.

There's no function for returning the list of outgoing edges but we can create it.
content.html:
This is the generic Graph class, which could be directed, undirected, etc. Incidents(v1) returns the set of edges that allow going from any vertex v to v1. In the case of an undirected graph, this function should return all edges that contain v1. In the case of a directed graph, it should return all edges, where the head (the destination) of each edge points to v1.

There's no function for returning the list of outgoing edges but we can create it.

content.raw:
The API has been clarified (hopefully) and extended:

* InDegree(vertex) -> int
* OutDegree(vertex) -> int
* AdjacentsFrom(vertex) -> vertices
* AdjacentsTo(vertex) -> vertices
* IncidentsFrom(vertex) -> edges
* IncidentsTo(vertex) -> edges

Let me know if now looks better.
content.html:
The API has been clarified (hopefully) and extended:

  • InDegree(vertex) -> int
  • OutDegree(vertex) -> int
  • AdjacentsFrom(vertex) -> vertices
  • AdjacentsTo(vertex) -> vertices
  • IncidentsFrom(vertex) -> edges
  • IncidentsTo(vertex) -> edges

Let me know if now looks better.

content.raw:
Would you like to consider an alternate parameter order? A vertex name feels like it should be the first argument, with data second, and id third. Reasons include:

1. A name should probably be enforced.
2. A user may not have data when creating a vertex. This user would like to use a default value.

I would propose the following definition:

```
public: Vertex<V> &AddVertex(const std::string &_name, const V &_data = V(), const VertexId &_id = kNullId)
```
content.html:
Would you like to consider an alternate parameter order? A vertex name feels like it should be the first argument, with data second, and id third. Reasons include:

  1. A name should probably be enforced.
  2. A user may not have data when creating a vertex. This user would like to use a default value.

I would propose the following definition:

public: Vertex<V> &AddVertex(const std::string &_name, const V &_data = V(), const VertexId &_id = kNullId)

content.raw: I was wondering about the heavy use of `std::set` in this implementation, because of the [high storage overhead](http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21449071/how-much-extra-memory-if-any-does-a-stdset-take-to-store-its-elements-v-s-a). It can see why the full graph has a `set` of vertices, because of the fast lookup speed, but why does `Edge` have one? Is there a situation where an `Edge` connects more than 2 vertices? Or does the `set` usage provide other benefits?
content.html: I was wondering about the heavy use of std::set in this implementation, because of the high storage overhead. It can see why the full graph has a set of vertices, because of the fast lookup speed, but why does Edge have one? Is there a situation where an Edge connects more than 2 vertices? Or does the set usage provide other benefits?

content.raw: I designed it using `std::set` because of the semantics. I thought that a set was a good match for representing the ends of an unconnected edge. Still considering if is the right decision.
content.html: I designed it using std::set because of the semantics. I thought that a set was a good match for representing the ends of an unconnected edge. Still considering if is the right decision.

content.raw: If I understand correctly it looks like both `DFS` and `BFS` return a list of vertices that are reachable from a starting vertex in the order they are found. I would expect a method calling itself `DFS` or `BFS` to accept a destination `VertexId` and return a path to it. I recommend renaming these methods to `ReachableDF` or similar to better indicate what they're returning.
content.html: If I understand correctly it looks like both DFS and BFS return a list of vertices that are reachable from a starting vertex in the order they are found. I would expect a method calling itself DFS or BFS to accept a destination VertexId and return a path to it. I recommend renaming these methods to ReachableDF or similar to better indicate what they're returning.

content.raw: The return of `DFS`/`BFS` is a list of vertices that are reachable from a starting vertex, that's correct. However, this list of vertices is not a path, it should be interpreted as the order in which the vertices were picked. We could add a destination node as you suggested, but this algorithm will be interpreted as a search algorithm in the sense that you could know if the target node is reachable. But as I mentioned before, the list of returned nodes is not going to be a path. I'll add this search algorithm when we submit the real pull request intended to be merged. What do you think?
content.html: The return of DFS/BFS is a list of vertices that are reachable from a starting vertex, that's correct. However, this list of vertices is not a path, it should be interpreted as the order in which the vertices were picked. We could add a destination node as you suggested, but this algorithm will be interpreted as a search algorithm in the sense that you could know if the target node is reachable. But as I mentioned before, the list of returned nodes is not going to be a path. I'll add this search algorithm when we submit the real pull request intended to be merged. What do you think?

content.raw: Could a boolean `visited` be part of some user-data on the vertex? There is a time-space trade off here where adding "visited" on to the vertex eliminates the find. A general way like adding an algorithmData pointer would save time for a lot of graph algorithms at the expense of only allowing one algorithm at a time to use a graph.
content.html: Could a boolean visited be part of some user-data on the vertex? There is a time-space trade off here where adding "visited" on to the vertex eliminates the find. A general way like adding an algorithmData pointer would save time for a lot of graph algorithms at the expense of only allowing one algorithm at a time to use a graph.

I wouldn't worry too much about the implementation details of the algorithms for now. We can improve them when we submit the real pull request intended to be merged. They were here as examples.

content.raw: Without implementing the optimization, is it possible to write an algorithm without the `find()` call using the graph library's API?
content.html: Without implementing the optimization, is it possible to write an algorithm without the find() call using the graph library's API?

Yes, it's possible. In this example, you can populate a local graph based on _graph but replacing the user data with a boolean value. This can be used to store whether the vertex has been visited or not. E.g.:

template<typename V, typename E, typename EdgeType>
std::vector<VertexId> DFS(const Graph<V, E, EdgeType> &_graph,
                                           const VertexId &_from)
{
  // Create an auxiliary graph, where the data is just a boolean value that
  // stores whether the vertex has been visited or not.
  Graph<bool, E, EdgeType> visitorGraph;

  // Copy the vertices (just the Id).
  for (auto const &v : _graph.Vertices())
    visitorGraph.AddVertex("", false, v.first);

  // Copy the edges (without data).
  for (auto const &e : _graph.Edges())
    visitorGraph.AddEdge(e.second.get().Vertices(), E());

  std::vector<VertexId> visited;
  std::stack<VertexId> pending({_from});

  while (!pending.empty())
  {
    auto vId = pending.top();
    pending.pop();

    // The vertex hasn't been visited yet.
    auto &vertex = visitorGraph.VertexFromId(vId);
    if (!vertex.Data())
    {
      vertex.Data() = true;
      visited.push_back(vId);
    }

    // Add more vertices to visit if they haven't been visited yet.
    auto adjacents = visitorGraph.AdjacentsFrom(vId);
    for (auto const &adj : adjacents)
    {
      vId = adj.first;
      auto &vertex = visitorGraph.VertexFromId(vId);
      if (!vertex.Data())
        pending.push(vId);
    }
  }

  return visited;
}

content.raw: humm I just noticed the `EdgeInitializer` above, I'll look more into what's happening here :)
content.html: humm I just noticed the EdgeInitializer above, I'll look more into what's happening here :)

The EdgeInitializer makes part of the magic for allowing uniform initialization with {}. We could make _data an optional argument in the EdgeInitializer too. However, because of how the optional parameters work on C++ we should be able to do:

// Create one edge specifying the vertices.
{{{0, 1}}}
// Create one edge specifying the vertices and data.
{{{0, 1}, "data"}}
// Create one edge specifying the vertices, data and weight.
{{{0, 1}, "data", 2.0}}

But this configuration wouldn't be possible:

// Create one edge specifying the vertices and weight.
{{{0, 1}, 2.0}}

content.raw: [This is a branch](#!/ignitionrobotics/ign-math/branches/compare/graph_generic_selector%0Dgraph_generic#diff) that I used for playing with additional template parameters that act as a selector for hiding/enabling member variables and functions and the `Edge` level. Just in case we want to go down that road...
content.html: This is a branch that I used for playing with additional template parameters that act as a selector for hiding/enabling member variables and functions and the Edge level. Just in case we want to go down that road...

content.raw:
Thanks for the clarification, I didn't meant to make this more difficult, I think it's ok the way it is.

I didn't give this much thought though, but I think one way we could support multiple optional fields would be to have a separate class like `EdgeOptions`, which contains weight and data for now, but could contain other things in the future. But anyway, I think we're making this more complicated than it needs to be :stuck_out_tongue_winking_eye: I think it's fine as it is.
content.html:
Thanks for the clarification, I didn't meant to make this more difficult, I think it's ok the way it is.

I didn't give this much thought though, but I think one way we could support multiple optional fields would be to have a separate class like EdgeOptions, which contains weight and data for now, but could contain other things in the future. But anyway, I think we're making this more complicated than it needs to be I think it's fine as it is.
